dc:description:
The relationship between NDUFB8 and Leigh syndrome spectrum was evaluated using the ClinGen Clinical Validity Framework as of November 23, 2020. The NDUFB8 gene encodes the NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductase (complex I) subunit B8, which is essential for complex I activity and assembly. Defects of this protein lead to complex I deficiency. 

The NDUFB8 gene was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive Leigh syndrome spectrum in 2018 (PMID: 29429571). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. This curation included four variants identified in two cases in one publication (PMID: 29429571). No segregation data were available. Loss of function is implicated as the mechanism of disease. This gene-disease association is also supported by biochemical function, functional alteration in non-patient cells, and animal models (PMIDs: 31127358, 27626371, 27509854).  

In summary, there is moderate evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the NICHD U24 ClinGen Mitochondrial Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel on November 23, 2020 (SOP Version 7).

evidence.dc:description: Scored for embryonic lethality, according to agreed rubric.
Homozygous knockout noted as having preweaning lethality, https://www.mousephenotype.org/data/genes/MGI:1914514
evidence.rdfs:label: International Mouse Phenotyping consortium

evidence.dc:description: NDUFB8  is a complex I subunit required for complex I assembly and complex I activity.

NDUFB8 HEK293 knock out cell lines were generated using the TALENS system. 
Blue-native (BN)– PAGE and immunoblot analysis for subunits NDUFA9, NDUFA13 and NDUFB11 showed that in the KO line complex I assembly was disrupted (Fig 1.).
evidence.rdfs:label: HEK293 knock out cell lines

evidence.dc:description: At least 10 further complex I genes have been associated with Leigh syndrome spectrum, scored increased to 2pts as per rubric.

The study built on previous structural models of the complex I core and used further cryo EM mapping to model the location and interactions of all subunits present in complex I from Bos Taurus. NDUF8 is an accessory subunit.
evidence.rdfs:label: Structural model of Complex I

evidence.dc:description:
c.432C>G(p.p.Cys144Trp) is predicted to affect splicing, using patient fibroblasts, RTPCR  showed that 40% of transcripts did not contain exon 4. FigS5 shows further analysis of the transcripts: of the whole cDNA 47% paternal allele, 14% maternal allele with exon 4, 39% maternal allele without exon 4. 
p.Pro76Gln is a conserved missense.
Transduction of a wt NDUFB8 viral construct rescued the complex I deficiency of patient fibroblasts (Table 1). Decreased basal and maximal respiration, as investigated by microscale respirometry was also rescued (Fig 2). 
Score increased for convincing functional evidence and rescue.

evidence.rdfs:label: P1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
3 months: acute respiratory failure, low consciousness and seizures
Periodically elevated concentrations of lactate in plasma (from 1.9 to 14.1; ref. <2.0 mmol/l) and cerebrospinal fluid (4, ref. <2.0 mmol/l) 
Brain MRI at the same age showed symmetrical signal alterations of midbrain, putamen and thalamus (Figure 2, upper panel).Repetitive brain MRI at the age of six months showed supratentorial and brainstem atrophy with cystic lesions in the bilateral putamina, thalami and midbrain (Figure 2, lower panel).
P1 developed hypertrophy of the left cardiac ventricle. 

He is currently aged 5.5 years and in a stable condition but completely dependent on the respirator and on full time care of parents for all daily life activities.
Muscle biopsy: homogenate of muscle tissue of P1 revealed isolated complex I deficiency (5.0% of citrate synthase [CS] activity, reference range > 6.7%).

non-consanguineous parents

evidence.dc:description:
The frameshift variant caused by 1bp deletion is located in exon 2 of 5, predicted to undergo NMD.
The decreased basal and maximal respiration as investigated by microscale respirometry, shown in the P2 fibroblast cell lines was rescued with transduction of the wild type NDUFB8 viral construct (Fig 2). Data was not given for rescue of complex I activity, it was noted the the fibroblast cell lines did not grow well.

evidence.rdfs:label: P2
evidence.detectionMethod: NGS panel: 215 genes, including genes with known associations to mitochondrial disorders and genes of CI subunits and assembly factors.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
At six months of age generalized muscular hypotonia and delayed development were noticed. His condition progressively worsened and he was hospitalized at seven months of age for vomiting and muscle wasting, died at 15 months.
Hyperlactatemia (5 mmol/L, ref. 0.9-1.7 mmol/L)
Cerebral scan revealed hypodensity of basal ganglia and internal capsule.
The activity of complex I was reduced in fibroblasts of P2 (7 nmol/min/mg protein, ref. 20.1–53.7) while cytochrome c oxidase (301 nmol/min/mg protein, ref. 62–139) and citrate synthase (99 nmol/min/mg protein, ref. 51–96) were elevated.

non-consanguineous parents
